Each instance of this object contains the configuration parameters for DHCP conditional serving based on the combination (logical AND) of the value of MAC address, OUI, DHCP options 60, 61, and 77.
This object is from TR98 issue 2 (WT107). This parameter is since version 1.4.
Enables or disables the DHCPConditionalServingPool entry. On creation, an entry is disabled by default.
Position of the pool entry in the order of precedence. For each DHCP discover, the lowest order (first) entry that matches the conditions determines the pool/forwarding.

Defines the source interface of the DHCP request that has to be matched. This value is the full hierarchical parameter name of a particular LAN**InterfaceConfig object or a WLANConfiguration object. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.
Defines a sub-string of the Vendor Class Identifier (Option 60) that has to be matched. Case sensitive. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.
Client Identifier (Option 61) for the specific IP connection of the client. A perfect match is needed. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.
Defines a sub-string of the User Class Identifier (Option 77) that has to be matched. Case sensitive. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.
MAC address of the physical interface of the DHCP client. A perfect match is needed. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.

Bit-mask for the MAC address, where matching of a packets MAC address with the Chaddr is only to be done for bit positions set to one in the mask. A mask of FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF indicates all bits of the Chaddr are to be used for classification. A perfect match is needed. An empty value indicates this criterion is not used for conditional serving.

If true, then the local DHCP server will assign an IP address from the specific address pool specified in this object. If false, the DHCP server will send the request to the DHCPServerIPAddress configured for this pool.
Specifies first address in the pool to be assigned by the DHCP server on the LAN interface.
Specifies last address in the pool to be assigned by the DHCP server on the LAN interface.
Comma separated list of IP addresses marked reserved from the address allocation pool.
Specifies the clients network subnet mask.
Comma separated list of DNS servers offered to DHCP clients. Support for more than three DNS Servers is Optional.
Sets the domain name to provide to clients on the LAN interface.
Comma separated list of IP addresses of routers on this subnet. Also known as default gateway. Support for more than one Router address is Optional.
Specifies the lease time in seconds of client assigned addresses. A value of -1 indicates an infinite lease.

Enumeration of: Normal UseAllocatedSubnet Passthrough If Normal, the DHCP addresses are to be allocated out of this private address pool entry. If UseAllocatedSubnet, instructs the CPE to allocate DHCP addresses from the WAN subnet block for the WAN connection identified in AssociatedConnection. If Passthrough, then the specified LAN Host identified by the Chaddr MAC address is given the WAN IP address.

Specifies the connection instance for the connection to be used for address allocation if UseAllocatedWAN is set ot UseAllocatedSubnet or Passthrough. The content is the full hierarchical parameter name of the default layer-3 connection object.
DHCP lease time in seconds given to the specified LAN Host when the WAN IP address is passed-through.

IP address of the DHCP server, where the request has to be sent to when there is a conditional match with this pool and LocallyServed is 0 (false). In case this parameter is not configured, then the DHCP message is dropped.
Number of DHCP options to be configured on the IGD, per LANDevice per DHCP Pool.
This object is a template for configuration of DHCP option. Each instance of this object represents a DHCP option for a specific DHCP pool.
The tag of the option as defined in RFC2132, uniquely identifying the DHCP option.
Base64 encoded octet string to be used as the Value of the DHCP option.
This object enables reporting of LAN-related device information and setting and configuring LAN IP addressing.
Enables or disables the DHCP server on the LAN interface.
The process id the dhcpv6 server launched for this connection. A pid of 0 indicates that no dhcp6s is running.
Indicating if the Dhcpv6 server is stateful or stateless.
This parameter is for assigning IPv6 address by stateful Dhcpv6 server instead of SLAAC. The value indicate the beginning of the interface ID pool. Zero compression by double-colon is not allowed.
This parameter is for assigning IPv6 address by stateful Dhcpv6 server instead of SLAAC. The value indicate the end of the interface ID pool. Zero compression by double-colon is not allowed.
Specifies the lease time in seconds of client assigned addresses. A value of -1 indicates an infinite lease.
Sets the domain name to provide to clients on the LAN interface.
Enumeration of: "Static" "DHCP" If Static, then DNS server addresses are to be manually specified. If DHCP, then the selected WAN connection DNS servers will be used.
Comma separated list of IPv6 DNS servers offered to DHCP clients. Support for more than three DNS Servers is Optional. Configurable when IPv6DNSConfigType is static.
Specifies the interface whose DNS servers will be advertised to LAN hosts. The content is the broadcom interface name. Example: ptm0, atm0, ppp0, eth0.
Number of IPv6 interface at LAN side of the CPE. 1 is a typical value for CPE not supporting Multihomed interfaces. Support for more than one interface instance is Optional.
Recursive DNS server.
DNS Search List.

This object models an 802.11 LAN connection on a CPE device. This object must be implemented for CPE that contain an 802.11 interface on the LAN side.

Since we support multiple SSID's, each SSID would be one instance of this WLANConfiguration object. However, because this object is defined by TR98 as non-writable, we have to create all 4 SSID's in the structure at modem bootup, but mark SSID 2-4 as disabled. Then when the user creates another SSID, we just mark one of the WLANConfiguration object instances as enabled.
Enables or disables this interface.
PSI name: WIRELESS_VAR.wlMode
Indicates the status of this interface. Enumeration of: "Up" "Error" "Disabled"
PSI name: BcmCfmWlanIfcCfg.status
The MAC address of the interface.
PSI name: BcmCfmWlanIfcCfg.mac
The maximum upstream and downstream bit rate available to this connection in Mbps. Either "Auto", or the largest of the OperationalDataTransmitRates values.
PSI name: WIRELESS_VAR.wlRate
The current radio channel used by the connection. Note: There is currently no way of requesting automatic selection of a channel.
PSI name: BcmCfmWlanIfcCfg.channel

The current service set identifier in use by the connection. The SSID is an identifier that is attached to packets sent over the wireless LAN that functions as a "password" for joining a particular radio network (BSS). Note: If an access point wishes to be known by more than one SSID, it must provide a WLANConfiguration instance for each SSID.
PSI name: BcmCfmWlanIfcCfg.ssid
The breacon types to be use with this connection. Enumeration of: "None" "Basic" "WPA" "11i" (Optional) "BasicandWPA" (Optional) "Basicand11i
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.tr69cBeaconType

Indicates whether MAC Address Control is enabled or not on this interface. MAC Address Control limits the clients that connect to those that match a list of allowed MAC addresses specified in InternetGatewayDevice.LANDevice.{i}.LAN- HostConfigManagement.AllowedMACAddresses.
PSI name: We do support MAC filter; TRUE.
Indicates which IEEE 802.11 mode the device is currently operating in. Enumeration of: "a" "b" "g"
PSI name: BcmCfmWlanIfcCfg.band or WIRELESS_VAR.wlBand
The index of the default WEP key.
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.keyIndex

A passphrase from which the WEP keys were generated. This parameter for information only-- the CPE is not responsible for generating the key based on the passphrase. This parameter is the same as the parameter InternetGatewayDevice.LANDevice.{i}.WLAN- Configuration.{i}.PreSharedKey.1.KeyPassprhase for the same instance of WLANConfiguration. When either parameter is changed, the value of the other is changed as well. This must either be a valid key length divided by 8, in which case each byte contributes 8 bits to the key, or else must consist of Hex digits and be a valid key length divided by 4, in which case each byte contributes 4 bits to the key. Note: If a passphrase is used, all four WEP keys will be the same. When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.
WiFi spec requires 64 hex

Comma-separated list of the supported key lengths. Each entry in the list is an enumeration of: "Disabled" "40-bit" "104-bit" Any additional vendor-specific values must start with the key length in bits.
PSI name: Broadcom also supports "64-bit" "128-bit"
Encryption modes that are available when basic 802.11 is enabled. "WEPEncryption" implies that all wireless clients can use WEP for data encryption. Enumeration of: "None" "WEPEncryption"
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.BasicEncryptionModes
Authentication modes that are available when basic 802.11 is enabled. Enumeration of: "None" "EAPAuthentication" (Optional)

PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.tr69cBasicAuthenticationMode Broadcom also supports the following authentication modes: "Open" "Share" "802.1X" "WPA" "WPA-PSK" "WPA2" "WPA2-PSK" "Mixed WPA2/WPA" "Mixed WPA2/WPA-PSK"

Encryption modes that are available when WPA is enabled. Enumeration of: "WEPEncryption" "TKIPEncryption" "WEPandTKIPEncryption" "AESEncryption" (Optional) "WEPandAESEncryption" (Optional) "TKIPandAESEncryption" (Optional) "WEPandTKIPandAESEncryption" (Optional)
PSI name: PWIRELESS_MSSID_VAR.wlWpa
Authentication modes that are available when WPA is enabled. Enumeration of: "PSKAuthentication" "EAPAuthentication" (Optional)
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.tr69cWPAAuthenticationMode

Encryption modes that are available when 802.11i is enabled. Enumeration of: "WEPEncryption" "TKIPEncryption" "WEPandTKIPEncryption" "AESEncryption" (Optional) "WEPandAESEncryption" (Optional) "TKIPandAESEncryption" (Optional) "WEPandTKIPandAESEncryption" (Optional)
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.tr69cIEEE11iEncryptionModes
Authentication modes that are available when 802.11i is enabled. Enumeration of: "PSKAuthentication" "EAPAuthentication" (Optional) "EAPandPSKAuthentication" (Optional)
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanSecCfg.tr69cIEEE11iAuthenticationMode

The possible radio channels for the wireless standard (a, b or g) and the regulatory domain. Comma-separated list. Ranges in the form "n-m" are permitted. For example, for 802.11b and North America, would be "1-11".

Comma-separated list of the maximum access point data transmit rates in Mbps for unicast, multicast and broadcast frames. For example, a value of "1,2", indicates that unicast, multicast and broadcast frames can be transmitted at 1 Mbps and 2 Mbps.
PSI name: BcmCfm_WlanIfcCfg.rate

Comma-separated list of the maximum access point data transmit rates in Mbps for unicast frames (a superset of BasicDataTransmitRates). Given the value of BasicDataTransmitRates from the example above, OperationalDataTransmit- Rates might be "1,2,5.5,11", indicating that unicast frames can additionally be transmitted at 5.5 Mbps and 11 Mbps.

Comma-separated list of the data transmit rates for unicast frames at which the access point will permit a station to connect (a subset of OperationalDataTransmitRates). Given the values of BasicDataTransmitRates and OperationalDataTransmitRates from the examples above, PossibleDataTransmitRates might be "1,2,5.5", indicating that the AP will only permit connections at 1 Mbps, 2 Mbps and 5.5 Mbps, even though it could theoretically accept connections at 11 Mbps.
Indicates whether insecure write access via mechanisms other than the CPE WAN Management Protocol is permitted to the parameters in this object.
Indicates whether or not the access point is sending out beacons.
Indicates whether or not beacons include the SSID name. This parameter has an effect only if BeaconAdvertisementEnabled is true.
Indicates whether or not the access point radio is enabled.
Indicates whether the access point can automatically reduce the data rate in the event of undue noise or contention.

An XML description of information used to identify the access point by name and physical location. The CPE is not expected to parse this string, but simply to treat it as an opaque string. An empty string indicates no location has been set.
802.11d Regulatory Domain String. First two octets are ISO/IEC 3166-1 two-character country code. The third octet is either " " (all environments), "O" (outside) or "I" (inside).
The number of times pre-shared key (PSK) authentication has failed (relevant only to WPA and 802.11i).
The number of times the MICHAEL integrity check has failed (relevant only to WPA and 802.11i)
The channels that the access point determines to be currently in use (including any that it is using itself). Comma-separated list. Ranges in the form "n-m" are permitted.

The current access-point operating mode. The optional modes permit the AP to be configured as a wireless bridge (to bridge two wired networks), repeater (a bridge that also serves wireless clients), or wireless station. Ad hoc stations are not supported. Enumeration of: "InfrastructureAccessPoint" "WirelessBridge" (Optional) "WirelessRepeater" (Optional) "WirelessStation" (Optional)
PSI name: WIRELESS_VAR.wlMode
The number of hops from the root access point to the wireless repeater or bridge.
The MAC address of the peer in wireless repeater or bridge mode.

Indicates whether another service is involved in client authentication (LinkAuthentication for a colocated authentication server; RadiusClient for an external RADIUS server). Enumeration of: "None" "LinkAuthentication" (Optional) "RadiusClient" (Optional)

This is a table of WEP keys. The size of this table is fixed with exactly 4 entries (with instance numbers 1 through 4). This object must be implemented for CPE that contain an 802.11 interface on the LAN side.

A WEP key expressed as a hexadecimal string. The WEP encryption level for a given key is inferred from the key length, e.g. 10 characters for 40-bit encryption, or 26 characters for 104-bit encryption (keys do not all have to be of the same length, although they will be if the CPE uses KeyPassphrase to generate them). If KeyPassphrase is written, all four WEP keys are immediately generated. The ACS SHOULD NOT set the passphrase and also set the WEP keys directly (the result of doing this is undefined). When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.

This is a table of preshared keys. The size of this table is fixed with exactly 10 entries (with instance numbers 1 through 10). This object must be implemented for CPE that contain an 802.11 interface on the LAN side.

A literal WPA PSK expressed as a hexadecimal string. The first table entry contains the default PreSharedKey (InternetGatewayDevice.LAN- Device.{i}.WLANConfiguration.{i}.PreShared- Key.1.PreSharedKey). When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.

A passphrase from which WEP or PSK keys were generated. This parameter for information only-- the CPE is not responsible for generating the key based on the passphrase. For WEP keys it must either be a valid key length divided by 8, in which case each byte contributes 8 bits to the key, or else must consist of Hex digits and be a valid key length divided by 4, in which case each byte contributes 4 bits to the key. For WPA PSK, the key is generated as specified by WPA, which uses PBKDF2 from PKCS #5: Password-based Cryptography Specification Version 2.0 (RFC2898).. Note: The 802.11i standard specifies rules for generation of WEP keys from a passphrase. When read, this parameter returns an empty string, regardless of the actual value.
WiFi spec requires 64 hex
The MAC address associated with a preshared key, or an empty string if no MAC address is associated with the key.

DefaultMode: Only one WAN service can be on this layer2 interface. VlanMuxMode: for multiple vlan interface base on this layer2 interface. MultipleService Mode: for multiple service over this layer2 connection.

This attribute sets the MoCA loopback configuration: 0 - No loopback, 1 - Loopback3, loopback of downstream traffic after PHY transceiver, depicted below. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 0. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte).

This attribute locks (1) and unlocks (0) the functions performed by this managed entity. When the administrative state is set to lock, all user functions of this UNI are blocked, and alarms, TCAs and AVCs for this managed entity and all dependent managed entities are no longer generated. Selection of a default value for this attribute is outside the scope of this document. (R, W) (mandatory) (1 byte).
This attribute indicates whether or not the managed entity is capable of performing its function. Valid values are enabled (0) and disabled (1). (R) (optional) (1 byte).
This parameter controls the state of the MoCA core. It can be started, stopped or restarted using this parameter. This parameter will always read "none".
This attribute denotes the maximum frame size allowed across this interface. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 6148. (R, W) (mandatory) (2 bytes).
This attribute is used to control alarm reporting from this managed entity. See I.1.8 for a complete description. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte)
This attribute provides a provisionable length of time. See I.1.8 for a complete description. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte)

This attribute controls filtering of PPPoE packets on this MoCA port. When its value is 1, all packets other than PPPoE packets are discarded. The default 0 accepts packets of all types. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte).

This attribute indicates the networking state of the MoCA interface. 0 - The interface has not joined a MoCA network, 1 - The interface has joined a MoCA network, 2 - The interface has joined a MoCA network and is currently the network coordinator. (R) (mandatory) (1 byte).
This attribute specifies the MoCA encryption key. It is an ASCII string of 17 decimal digits. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 17 null bytes. (R, W) (mandatory) (17 bytes).
This attribute activates (1) link-layer security. The default value 0 deactivates it. (R, W) (mandatory) (1 byte).
Indicates a user configured threshold for PHY link bandwidth between two nodes that will raise an alarm. The value 0 disables the threshold. (R, W) (optional) (2 bytes)

This attribute is a bit map of the center frequencies that the interface is permitted to use, where each bit represents a center frequency. The least significant bit (b[0]) corresponds to center frequency 800MHz. The next significant bit (b[1]) corresponds to center frequency 825 MHz. The 28th bit (b[27]) corresponds to a center frequency 1500 MHz. The 4 most significant bits are not used. (R, W) (optional) (4 bytes).
This attribute reports the frequency to which the MoCA interface is currently tuned, in MHz. (R) (mandatory) (2 byte).
This attribute reports the frequency to which the MoCA interface was tuned when last operational, in MHz. (R) (mandatory) (2 byte).
Setting the MoCA behaviour during Network Admission. 0-AutoNegotiate for NC, 1-Always NC, 2-Never NC.
Enable MoCA for automatic network search, using the LOF and FREQ_MASK parameters. When FALSE, MoCA uses only the LOF value to join the network.

Transmit Power Control setting. When TRUE, the transmit power level is adjusted to a setting that will achieve the Max target PHY bit rate. The adjusted power setting will be less than or equal to Tx power. When FALSE, the transmit power level is set to <Tx Power>.

Ability to transmit in a constant power mode as defined by the spec. It is used only for lab testing. Tx channel will be LOF. 0-Normal Operation, 1-Tx Mode, 2-Rx Mode, 3-External Control, 4-CW mode, 5-Single tone mode (default sub-carrier), 6-single tone mode (user sub-carrier), 7-dual tone mode (user sub-carrier).

Setting the MoCA node operation for data traffic for Multicast traffic. 0 - Normal mode, 1-MCast Bcast Mode. Normal mode is when we have a host with IGMP snooping ability. For CTP testing, the BC mode should be used.
Turning on the lab mode will enable SNR/IQ graphs in BBS. This mode limits the network to 8 nodes.
DEPRECATED A special BRCM mode that allows classification according to side band QTAG field, instead of VLAN PRIO. 0-Standard, 1-QTAG classification.
Max transmit time in micro secs. Max tx time allowed to transmit a frame through the MoCA physical interface. Used for limitng aggregation.
DEPRECATED Max Tx Power Level allowed in dBm units. Range:-27-3, default is 3dBM.
Units in terms of 0.5 dBs. So, 3 dB of SNR margin will have a value of 6 here.
A request for an Out-Of-Order LMO to any node.
Control setting to turn on/off LMO reporting.
RF channel number of the lowest frequency channel covered by the Taboo Channel Mask field. 32 is the lowest value allowed for this field, corresponding to 800 Mhz center frequency.

Ability to change Taboo Frequency Mask. MSB corresponds to the lowest Taboo channel as identified in the TABOO_MASK_START field. Each consecutive bit then corresponds to channels offset by multiples of 25 Mhz. A bit in the Taboo_Channel_Mask field is set to '1' if the corresponding channel is taboo. Only the 24 msb is relevant. i.e., 0xHHHHHH00, where H represents any Hex number.
Operation mode for the CTP (certification test plan) of inserting IE in every RR.
Operation mode for the Certification Test Plan of inserting 8 IEs in every MAP.
Maximum allowed packets for aggregated transmissions.
DEPRECATED Set Max Constellation on all carriers in the receive from a specified node. Value 16 indicates ALL NODES.
DEPRECATED Max Constellation, 1-BPSK, 2-QPSK, 3-QAM8, 4-QAM16, 5-QAM32, 6-QAM64, 7-QAM128. 8-QAM256.
Preferred NC nodes have a preference over the other nodes in the MoCA Network to become the NC node.
PMK interval time. This configuration will take effect only after the next key change. It is in hrs.
TEK intervals time. This configuration will take effect only after the next key change. It is in terms of minutes.
A debug trace mask or level that is passed into the driver.

When application sets this to true, the RCL handler function will reset the trace level in the driver. Then the RCL handler function will set this parameter back to FALSE. So when read, this variable will always be FALSE.
A sequence number that the MR Entry Node received to operate at Assigned MoCA channel in band M.

Parameter string used for initialization of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl start" or "mocactl restart". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.

Parameter string used for configuration of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl config". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.

Parameter string used for setting trace level of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl trace". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.
For WAN service connection limits and defaults to TRUE. If TRUE, the MaxConnections contains the number of allowable WAN services for the layer 2 interface.
This parameter shows the max number layer 3 connections allowed for the interface If LimitedConnections is set to TRUE. For Auto Detection (BHR), it is set to 1.

This object models an Epon LAN connection on a CPE device. This object must be implemented for CPE that contain an Epon interface on the LAN side.

Indicates the status of this interface. Enumeration of: "Up" "NoLink" "Error" "Disabled"
Linux interface name for this interface, e.g. epon0. . This field is filled in by the system. So it is read-only.
The physical address of the interface.

Indicates whether MAC Address Control is enabled or not on this interface. MAC Address Control limits the clients that connect to those that match a list of allowed MAC addresses specified in InternetGatewayDevice.LANDevice.{i}.LAN- HostConfigManagement.AllowedMACAddresses.

This object provides information about each of the hosts on the LAN, including those whose IP address was allocated by the CPE using DHCP as well as hosts with statically allocated IP addresses.
Number of entries in the Host table.
We never write the value of this counter to the config file because we never write out the individual host entries.
Host table.
Current IP Address of the host.

Indicates whether the IP address of the host was allocated by the CPE using DHCP, was assigned to the host statically, or was assigned using automatic IP address allocation. Enumeration of: "DHCP" "Static" "AutoIP"
DHCP lease time remaining in seconds. A value of -1 indicates an infinite lease. The value must be 0 (zero) if the AddressSource is not DHCP.
MAC address of the host.
The device
Type of physical interface through which this host is connected to the CPE. Enumeration of: "Ethernet" "USB" "802.11" "HomePNA" "HomePlug" "Other"

Whether or not the host is currently present on the LAN. The method of presence detection is a local matter to the CPE. The ability to list inactive hosts is Optional. If the CPE includes inactive hosts in this table, this variable MUST be set to zero for each inactive host. The length of time an inactive host remains listed in this table is a local matter to the CPE.
Linux interface name for this ethernet port, e.g. eth0, eth1, eth1.2, eth1.3.
Each instance contains all objects associated with a particular physical WAN interface.
Number of instances of WANConnectionDevice in this WANDevice.

Used to enable or disable access to and from the Internet across all connection instances.

Broadcom also adding X_BROADCOM_COM_Moca access type. We not not allow POTS wan access type.
Specifies the maximum upstream theoretical bit rate for the WAN device in bits per second.
Specifies the maximum downstream theoretical bit rate for the WAN device in bits per second.
Indicates the state of the physical connection (link) from WANDevice to a connected entity. Enumeration of: "Up" "Down" "Initializing" "Unavailable"
Name of the Service Provider providing link connectivity on the WAN.
The cumulative counter for total number of bytes sent upstream across all connection service instances on the WAN device.
The cumulative counter for total number of bytes received downstream across all connection service instances on the WAN device.
The cumulative counter for total number of packets (IP or PPP) sent upstream across all connection service instances on the WAN device.
The cumulative counter for total number of packets (IP or PPP) received downstream across all connection service instances on the WAN device.

Active connection table.

Specifies a WAN connection device object associated with this connection instance. The content is the full hierarchical parameter name of the WAN connection device. Example: "Internet- GatewayDevice.WANDevice.1.WANConnection- Device.2".

Specifies a WAN connection object associated with this connection instance. The content is the full hierarchical parameter name of the layer-3 connection object. Example: "InternetGateway- Device.WANDevice.1.WANConnectionDevice.2.- WANPPPConnection.1".

ATU-R Vendor Revision Number as defined in T1.413 Issue 2.

Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of Total statistics. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this may not always be possible.
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSLWAN:1, ADSL2WAN:1, VDSL2WAN:1
Number of seconds since the most recent DSL Showtime--the beginning of the period used for collection of Showtime6 statistics.
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSLWAN:1, ADSL2WAN:1, VDSL2WAN:1

Number of seconds since the second most recent DSL Showtime--the beginning of the period used for collection of LastShowtime statistics. If the CPE has not retained information about the second most recent Showtime (e.g., on reboot), the start of LastShowtime statistics MAY temporarily coincide with the start of Showtime statistics.

Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of CurrentDay statistics. The CPE MAY align the beginning of each CurrentDay interval with days in the UTC time zone, but is not required to do so. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this may not always be possible.

Number of seconds since the beginning of the period used for collection of QuarterHour statistics. The CPE MAY align the beginning of each QuarterHour interval with real-time quarter-hour intervals, but is not required to do so. Statistics SHOULD continue to be accumulated across CPE reboots, though this may not always be possible.

parameter.name: StandardsSupported
parameter.defaultValue: G.992.1_Annex_A, G.992.1_Annex_B, G.992.1_Annex_C, T1.413, G.992.2, G.992.3_Annex_A, G.992.3_Annex_B, G.992.3_Annex_C, G.992.3_Annex_I, G.992.3_Annex_L, G.993.1, G.993.1_Annex_A, G.993.2_Annex_A, G.993.2_Annex_B, G.993.2_Annex_C

xmlMandatorySingleRootNode.description: Indicates which DSL standards and recommendations are supported by the B-NT. Comma-seperated list of strings. Each element in the list is one of: "G.992.1_Annex_A" "G.992.1_Annex_B" "G.992.1_Annex_C" "T1.413" "T1.413i2" "ETSI_101_388" "G.992" "G.992.3_Annex_A" "G.992.3_Annex_B" "G.992.3_Annex_C" "G.992.3_Annex_I" "G.992.3_Annex_J" "G.992.3_Annex_M" "G.993.1" "G.993.1_Annex_A" "G.993.2_Annex_A" "G.993.2_Annex_B" "G.993.2_Annex_C"
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSL2WAN:1, VDSL2WAN:1
Indicates the standard that the B-NT is using for the connection. The value MUST be a member of the list reported by the StandardsSupported parameter.
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSL2WAN:1, VDSL2WAN:1

Indicates which VDSL2 profiles are allowed on the line. Comma-separated list of strings. Each element in the list is one of : "8a" "8b" "8c" "8d" "12a" "12b" "17a" "17b" "30a" Note: In G.997.1, this parameter is called PROFILES. See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.
Note: This parameter is OPTIONAL at the G and S/T interfaces in G.997.1 Amendment 1. If the parameter is implemented but no value is available, its value MUST be an empty string. The profile 35b is equivalent to the deprecated parameter X_BROADCOM_COM_Priv1.

Indicates which VDSL2 profile is currently in use on the line. The value MUST be a member of the list reported by the AllowedProfiles parameter, or an empty string as noted below.
Note: This parameter is OPTIONAL at the G and S/T interfaces in G.997.1 Amendment 1. If the parameter is implemented but no value is available, its value MUST be an empty string.

This parameter contains the estimated electrical loop length expressed in dB at 1 MHz, kle (see O-UPDATE in section 12.2.4.2.1.2/G.993.2). The value SHALL be coded as an unisgned 16-bit number in the range 0 (coded as 0) to 128 dB (coded as 1280) in steps of 0.1 dB.

Reports whether trellis coding is enabled in the downstream direction. A value of 1 indicates that trellis coding is in use, and a value of 0 indicates that the trellis is disabled.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendtion G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to -1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

Reports whether trellis coding is enabled in the upstream direction. A value of 1 indicates that trellis coding is in use, and a value of 0 indicates that the trellis is disabled.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendtion G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to -1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

Reports whether the OPTIONAL virtual noise mechanism is in use in the downstream direction. A value of 1 indicates the virtual noise mechanism is not in use, and a value of 2 indicates the virtual noise mechanism is in use.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

Reports whether the OPTIONAL virtual noise mechanism is in use in the upstream direction. A value of 1 indicates the virtual noise mechanism is not in use, and a value of 2 indicates the virtual noise mechanism is in use.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

Reports the actual cyclic extension, as the value of m, in use for the connection.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 99.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

The curent signal-to-noise ratio margin of each band. Comma-separated list of values. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

The curent signal-to-noise ratio margin of each upstream band. Comma-separated list of values. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2WAN:1

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_8a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "8a" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_8b This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "8b" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_8c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "8c" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_8d This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "8d" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_12a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "12a" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_12b This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "12b" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_17a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "17a" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_30a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "30a" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_BrcmPriv1 This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "BrcmPriv1" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification. This parameter has been deprecated. It is replaced by X_BROADCOM_COM_VDSL_ 35b.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_35b This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "35b" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.

adslConfig bit VDSL_PROFILE_BrcmPriv2 This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure which VDSL profile "BrcmPriv2" is allowed on the line. The read only parameter of allowed profiles for the line is AllowedProfiles which is defined in TR98 Amendmend 2 specification.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106a" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_212a This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "212a" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106b This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106b" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_106c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "106c" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit FAST_PROFILE_212c This Broadcom proprietary parameter allows users to configure FAST profile "212c" which is allowed on the line.
adslConfig bit VDSL_US0_8a This Broadcom proprietary parameter will soon be turned into the standard parameter US0MASK, which is a version 1.3 (WT-107) parameter.

Is DSL Bonding enabled on this line? When mdm_initdsl initializes this object, it will set enableBonding to TRUE.

Indicates the line number for bonding. Only 0 or 1 is allowed because we only bond 2 lines. This param should be read-only. But I marked it ReadWrite so line 1 will get written out to the config file. This is another case where we need an attribute which is for read-only params, something like "writeToConfigFileIfNotDefault"

This is the full path (in TR-098 style, without trailing dot) of the other line which forms this bonding pair. For example, WANDevice.12.WanDslInterfaceConfig This param should be read-only. But I marked it ReadWrite so the entry will get written out to the config file. This is another case where we need an attribute which is for read-only params, something like "writeToConfigFileIfNotDefault"

This object contains the DSL test parameters that are available during the L0 (i.e., Showtime) state.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the downstream direction for HLOGpsds. Valid Values are 1, 2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this arameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the upstream direction for HLOGpsds. Valid Values are 1, 2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this arameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Downstream logarithmic channel characteristics per sub-carrier group. Comma-separated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elments will depend on the value of HLOGGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None"
Note: HLOGpsds is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.

Upstream logarithmic channel characteristics per sub-carrier group. Comma-separated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elments will depend on the value of HLOGGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None"
Note: HLOGpsds is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.

Indicates the number of symbols over which HLOGpsds was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Indicates the number of symbols over which HLOGpsus was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the downstream direction for QLNpsds. Valid values are 1,2, 4 and 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the upstream direction for QLNpsds. Valid values are 1,2, 4 and 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Downsteam quiet line noise per subcarrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3 and G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of QLNGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: QLNpsds is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.

Upsteam quiet line noise per subcarrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3 and G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of QLNGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: QLNpsds is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.

Indicates the number of symbols over which QLNpsds was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Indicates the number of symbols over which QLNpsus was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in teh downstream direction for SNRpsds. Valid values are 1,2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in teh upstream direction for SNRpsds. Valid values are 1,2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.

Downstream SNR per subcarrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of SNRGds but will not exceed 512. Intepretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not appply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: SNRpsds is first measured during initialization and is updated during Showtime.

Upstream SNR per subcarrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 64 for G.992.3, and G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of SNRGus but will not exceed 512. Intepretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not appply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: SNRpsus is first measured during initialization and is updated during Showtime.

Indicates the number of symbols over which SNRpsds was measured.
Note: see ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Indicates the number of symbols over which SNRpsus was measured.
Note: see ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Downstream line attenuation per usable band, as computed during initialization. Comma-seperated list of values. Number of elements is dependent on the number of downstream bands but will exceed one only for G.993.2. Interpretation of LATNpbds is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.

Upstream line attenuation per usable band, as computed during initialization. Comma-seperated list of values. Number of elements is dependent on the number of upstream bands but will exceed one only for G.993.2. Interpretation of LATNpbus is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.

Downstream signal attenuation per usable band, as computed during L0 (i.e., Showtime) state. Comma-seperated list of values. Number of elements is dependent on the number of downstream bands but will exceed one only for G.933.2. Interpretation of SATNpbds is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.

Upstream signal attenuation per usable band, as computed during L0 (i.e., Showtime) state. Comma-seperated list of values. Number of elements is dependent on the number of upstream bands but will exceed one only for G.933.2. Interpretation of SATNpbds is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1.

This object models physical layer properties specific to a single Ethernet physical connection used for Internet access on a CPE. This object is intended for a CPE with an Ethernet WAN interface, and is exclusive of any other WAN
Enables or disables this interface.
Indicates the status of this interface. Enumeration of: "Up" "NoLink" "Error" "Disabled"
The physical address of the interface.
The maximum upstream and downstream bit rate available to this connection. Enumeration of: "10" "100" "Auto"
The duplex mode available to this connection. Enumeration of: "Half" "Full" "Auto"
Rate to shape this connection
Burst Size in bytes.

Linux interface name for this ethernet port, e.g. eth0, eth1, eth1.2, eth1.3 Small hack here: this parameter should be read-only. But if it is read-only, then it would not get written out to config file. Setting alwaysWriteToConfigFile in the data model also does not work right, since it will write out the ifName for this object under all WANDevices. What we need is another attribute called writeToConfigFileIfNotDefaultValue.

DefaultMode: Only one WAN service can be on this layer2 interface. VlanMuxMode: for multiple vlan interface base on this layer2 interface. MultipleService Mode: for multiple service over this layer2 connection.

If there is an enet port defined in boardparams.c as a WAN port, this variable will be set to TRUE and this enet port will be initialized as a WAN port and will not be included in the default bridge group (br0).
For WAN service connection limits and defaults to TRUE. If TRUE, the X_BROADCOM_COM_MaxConnections contains the number of allowable WAN services for the layer 2 interface.
This parameter shows the max number layer 3 connections allowed for the interface If X_BROADCOM_COM_LimitedConnections is set to TRUE. For Auto Detection (BHR), it is set to 1.
Indicates whether GMAC is enabled or not on this interface. GMAC port is a ethernet port with 1+1 Gbit speed.
Indicates whether the ethernet port is WAN only, LAN only or WAN/LAN determined by the hardware and default board parameters.
This object contains statistics for an Ethernet WAN interface on a CPE device.
Total number of bytes sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of bytes received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of packets sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of packets received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of received packets that get dropped on this connection.
Total number of transmit errors on this connection.
Total number of receive errors on this connection.
Total number of transmit error on this connection.
Total number of multicast packets sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of multicast packets received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of multicast bytes sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of multicast bytes received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of unicast packets sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of unticast packets received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of broadcast packets sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of broadcast packets received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.

This object models physical layer properties specific to a single Wlan physical connection used for Internet access on a CPE. This object is intended for a CPE with an Wlan WAN interface, and is exclusive of any other WAN
Enables or disables this interface.
Indicates the status of this interface. Enumeration of: "Up" "NoLink" "Error" "Disabled"
The physical address of the interface.
This object contains statistics for an Wan Wifi Interface WAN interface on a CPE device.
Total number of bytes sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of bytes received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of packets sent over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Total number of packets received over the interface since the CPE was last reset.
Moca Interface on the WAN side.
Controls whether this Moca interface is enabled or not.
Indicates the status of this interface. Enumeration of: "Up" "NoLink" "Error" "Disabled"

Linux interface name for this moca interface, e.g. moca0 or moca1 Small hack here: this parameter should be read-only. But if it is read-only, then it would not get written out to config file. Setting alwaysWriteToConfigFile in the data model also does not work right, since it will write out the ifName for this object under all WANDevices. What we need is another attribute called writeToConfigFileIfNotDefaultValue.

DefaultMode: Only one WAN service can be on this layer2 interface. VlanMuxMode: for multiple vlan interface base on this layer2 interface. MultipleService Mode: for multiple service over this layer2 connection.

This attribute sets the MoCA loopback configuration: 0 - No loopback, 1 - Loopback3, loopback of downstream traffic after PHY transceiver, depicted below. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 0. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte).

This attribute locks (1) and unlocks (0) the functions performed by this managed entity. When the administrative state is set to lock, all user functions of this UNI are blocked, and alarms, TCAs and AVCs for this managed entity and all dependent managed entities are no longer generated. Selection of a default value for this attribute is outside the scope of this document. (R, W) (mandatory) (1 byte).
This attribute indicates whether or not the managed entity is capable of performing its function. Valid values are enabled (0) and disabled (1). (R) (optional) (1 byte).
This parameter controls the state of the MoCA core. It can be started, stopped or restarted using this parameter. This parameter will always read "none".
This attribute denotes the maximum frame size allowed across this interface. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 6148. (R, W) (mandatory) (2 bytes).
This attribute is used to control alarm reporting from this managed entity. See I.1.8 for a complete description. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte)
This attribute provides a provisionable length of time. See I.1.8 for a complete description. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte)

This attribute controls filtering of PPPoE packets on this MoCA port. When its value is 1, all packets other than PPPoE packets are discarded. The default 0 accepts packets of all types. (R, W) (optional) (1 byte).

This attribute indicates the networking state of the MoCA interface. 0 - The interface has not joined a MoCA network, 1 - The interface has joined a MoCA network, 2 - The interface has joined a MoCA network and is currently the network coordinator. (R) (mandatory) (1 byte).
This attribute specifies the MoCA encryption key. It is an ASCII string of 17 decimal digits. Upon ME instantiation, the ONT sets this attribute to 17 null bytes. (R, W) (mandatory) (17 bytes).
This attribute activates (1) link-layer security. The default value 0 deactivates it. (R, W) (mandatory) (1 byte).
Indicates a user configured threshold for PHY link bandwidth between two nodes that will raise an alarm. The value 0 disables the threshold. (R, W) (optional) (2 bytes)

This attribute is a bit map of the center frequencies that the interface is permitted to use, where each bit represents a center frequency. The least significant bit (b[0]) corresponds to center frequency 800MHz. The next significant bit (b[1]) corresponds to center frequency 825 MHz. The 28th bit (b[27]) corresponds to a center frequency 1500 MHz. The 4 most significant bits are not used. (R, W) (optional) (4 bytes).
This attribute reports the frequency to which the MoCA interface is currently tuned, in MHz. (R) (mandatory) (2 byte).
This attribute reports the frequency to which the MoCA interface was tuned when last operational, in MHz. (R) (mandatory) (2 byte).
Setting the MoCA behaviour during Network Admission. 0-AutoNegotiate for NC, 1-Always NC, 2-Never NC.
Enable MoCA for automatic network search, using the LOF and FREQ_MASK parameters. When FALSE, MoCA uses only the LOF value to join the network.

Transmit Power Control setting. When TRUE, the transmit power level is adjusted to a setting that will achieve the Max target PHY bit rate. The adjusted power setting will be less than or equal to Tx power. When FALSE, the transmit power level is set to <Tx Power>.

Ability to transmit in a constant power mode as defined by the spec. It is used only for lab testing. Tx channel will be LOF. 0-Normal Operation, 1-Tx Mode, 2-Rx Mode, 3-External Control, 4-CW mode, 5-Single tone mode (default sub-carrier), 6-single tone mode (user sub-carrier), 7-dual tone mode (user sub-carrier).

Setting the MoCA node operation for data traffic for Multicast traffic. 0 - Normal mode, 1-MCast Bcast Mode. Normal mode is when we have a host with IGMP snooping ability. For CTP testing, the BC mode should be used.
Turning on the lab mode will enable SNR/IQ graphs in BBS. This mode limits the network to 8 nodes.
DEPRECATED A special BRCM mode that allows classification according to side band QTAG field, instead of VLAN PRIO. 0-Standard, 1-QTAG classification.
Max transmit time in micro secs. Max tx time allowed to transmit a frame through the MoCA physical interface. Used for limitng aggregation.
DEPRECATED Max Tx Power Level allowed in dBm units. Range:-27-3, default is 3dBM.
Units in terms of 0.5 dBs. So, 3 dB of SNR margin will have a value of 6 here.
A request for an Out-Of-Order LMO to any node.
Control setting to turn on/off LMO reporting.
RF channel number of the lowest frequency channel covered by the Taboo Channel Mask field. 32 is the lowest value allowed for this field, corresponding to 800 Mhz center frequency.

Ability to change Taboo Frequency Mask. MSB corresponds to the lowest Taboo channel as identified in the TABOO_MASK_START field. Each consecutive bit then corresponds to channels offset by multiples of 25 Mhz. A bit in the Taboo_Channel_Mask field is set to '1' if the corresponding channel is taboo. Only the 24 msb is relevant. i.e., 0xHHHHHH00, where H represents any Hex number.
Operation mode for the CTP (certification test plan) of inserting IE in every RR.
Operation mode for the Certification Test Plan of inserting 8 IEs in every MAP.
Maximum allowed packets for aggregated transmissions.
DEPRECATED Set Max Constellation on all carriers in the receive from a specified node. Value 16 indicates ALL NODES.
DEPRECATED Max Constellation, 1-BPSK, 2-QPSK, 3-QAM8, 4-QAM16, 5-QAM32, 6-QAM64, 7-QAM128. 8-QAM256.
Preferred NC nodes have a preference over the other nodes in the MoCA Network to become the NC node.
PMK interval time. This configuration will take effect only after the next key change. It is in hrs.
TEK intervals time. This configuration will take effect only after the next key change. It is in terms of minutes.
A debug trace mask or level that is passed into the driver.

When application sets this to true, the RCL handler function will reset the trace level in the driver. Then the RCL handler function will set this parameter back to FALSE. So when read, this variable will always be FALSE.
A sequence number that the MR Entry Node received to operate at Assigned MoCA channel in band M.

Parameter string used for initialization of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl start" or "mocactl restart". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.

Parameter string used for configuration of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl config". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.

Parameter string used for setting trace level of MoCA interface. The format of the string is the same as the CLI parameter format for commands "mocactl trace". Default value is NULL string meaning that the moca daemon will use its default values.

If there is moca port defined in boardparams.c as a WAN port, this variable will be set to TRUE and this moca port will be initialized as a WAN port and will not be included in the default bridge group (br0).
For WAN service connection limits and defaults to TRUE. If TRUE, the MaxConnections contains the number of allowable WAN services for the layer 2 interface.
This parameter shows the max number layer 3 connections allowed for the interface If LimitedConnections is set to TRUE. For Auto Detection (BHR), it is set to 1.

This object contains per tunnel L2TP Access Concentrator (LAC) config settings. Individual sessions in this tunnel are configured in the L2TP AC Link Config object.
Is this tunnel enabled.
The user friendly name of the L2TP Tunnel.
IP address of the LNS (the server which our L2TP AC talks to).
Indicates the state of the L2TP tunnel.

This is an id that is created when the tunnel is created. It must be passed to ppp when it tries to run over the tunnel. The l2tp LAC userspace daemon sends this info to ssk. ssk writes it into this param. Therefore, it is read-only.
Specify which UDP port xl2tpd should use. The default is 1701.

This object is intended for a CPE with a DSL modem WAN interface. This object is OBSOLETED in TR98 Admendment 2.
Number of table entries in the ConnectionService table.
This table contains an entry for each connection service. This object is OBSOLETED in TR98 Admendment 2.

Specifies a WAN connection device object associated with this connection instance. The content is the full hierarchical parameter name of the WAN connection device. Example: "Internet- GatewayDevice.WANDevice.1.WANConnection- Device.2".

This object is to provide diagnostic information for a CPE with an ADSL2 or ADSL2+ modem WAN interface, but MAY also be used for ADSL.

Indicates availability of diagnostic data. One of: "None" "Requested" "Complete" Value may be set to Requested to initiate the diagnostic test, which brings down the DSL connection while the test is operating. When writing, the only allowed value is Requested. When requested, the CPE SHOULD wait until after completion of the communication session with the ACS before starting the diagnostic. When the diagnostic initiated by the ACS is completed, the CPE MUST establish a new connection to the ACS to allow the ACS to view the results, indicating the corresponding reason in the Inform message.
REPORT_PROFILE: DSLDiagnostics:1, ADSL2DSLDiagnostics:1, VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1
Downstream actual power spectral density. Interpretation of the value is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.

REPORT_PROFILE: DSLDiagnostics:1, ADSL2DSLDiagnostics:1, VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

REPORT_PROFILE: DSLDiagnostics:1
Downstream gain allocation per subcarrier. Comma-separated list of integers. Maximum number of elements is 256 for ADSL and ADSL2, 512 for ADSL2
REPORT_PROFILE: DSLDiagnostics:1

Scaling used to represent the upstream linear channel characteristics. Interpretation of the value is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSL2DSLDiagnostics:1, VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the downstream direction for HLINpsds. Valid vlaues are 1, 2, 4, and 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group in the upstream direction for HLINpsds. Valid vlaues are 1, 2, 4, and 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Upstream linear channel characteristics per subcarrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. Maximum number of complex pairs is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.003.2, the number of pairs will depend on the value of HLINGds but it will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the value is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: HLIN is not applicable in PLOAM for G.992.1 or G.992.2.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to "None".
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSL2DSLDiagnostics:1, VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group int he downstream direction for HLOGpsds. Valid values are 1, 2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multiode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Number of sub-carriers per sub-carrier group int he upstream direction for HLOGpsds. Valid values are 1, 2, 4, 8.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multiode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 1.
REPORT_PROFILE: VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Downstream logarithmic channel characteristics per sub-carrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of HLOGGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: HLOGpsds is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.
REPORT_PROFILE: ADSL2DSLDiagnostics:1, VDSL2DSLDiagnostics:1

Upstream logarithmic channel characteristics per sub-carrier group. Comma-seperated list of values. The maximum number of elements is 256 for G.992.3, and 512 for G.992.5. For G.993.2, the number of elements will depend on the value of HLOGGds but will not exceed 512. Interpretation of the values is as defined in ITU-T Rec. G.997.1.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter SHOULD be set to "None."
Note: HLOGpsus is measured during initialization and is not updated during Showtime.

Indicates the number of symbols over which HLOGpsds was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

Indicates the number of symbols over which QLNpsus was measured.
Note: See ITU-T Recommendation G.997.1. For a multimode device operating in a mode in which this parameter does not apply, the value of this parameter SHOULD be set to 0.

This object is a Broadcom proprietiary object for a CPE with an ADSL2 or ADSL2
This object contains Peak Line Noise Diagnostics data
Indicates availability of diagnostic data. One of:
Threshold used for "broadband" measurements (in dB format). For example, -4. This parameter is required before starting PLN measurement.
Threshold used for "per tones" measurements (in dB format). For example, -4. This parameter is required before starting PLN measurement.
Number of Duration bins used in PLN measurement. This parameter is optional; however, if PLNDurationBins is set, this parameter is required. Note: when read, this parameter is always 32.
Interval definition for the impulse duration histogram, {M0, M1, , Mn-1}, where n is 32. For example, for bin table of 4 bins, it is "1,2,3,4"
Number of inter-arrival bins used in PLN measurement. This parameter is optional; however, if PLNIntrArvBins is set, this parameter is required. Note: when read, this parameter is always 16.
Interval definition for the impulse inter-arrival histogram, {N0, N1, , Nn-1}, where n is 15. For example, for bin table of 4 bins, it is "1,2,3,4"
Actual peak line noise measurents per tone (in dB format)
Counters of threshold violations per tone (in dB format).
Impulse duration histogram.
Impulse inter-arrival histogram.
Per Tone Measurement Counter , 32-bit unsigned integer indicating number of DMT symbols during which PLN Per Tone measurement is done
Broadband Measurement Counter , 32-bit unsigned integer indicating number of DMT symbols during which PLN broadband measurement is done
This object contains Nonlinearity Diagnostics data
Additional visible noise due to non-linearity (in dB).
Number of bits per symbol lost due to non-linearity
SNR degradation due to non-linearities, per bin in dB format.
This object models the cellular physical layer properties used for Internet access on a CPE. This object is intended for a CPE with an cellular WAN interface.
The path name of a row in InternetGatewayDevice.Device.Cellular.Interface table;

Each instance contains objects associated with a given WAN link. In this case of DSL, each instance corresponds to a single ATM VC. On creation of a WANConnectionDevice instance, there are initially no connection objects contained within. BRCM NOTE: This object appears in two profiles, Baseline:1 P and ADSLWAN:1 PC
Number of instances of WANIPConnection in this WANConnectionDevice.
Number of instances of WANPPPConnection in this WANConnectionDevice.

This object is provides access to an ATM-layer F5 OAM loopback test.

Indicates availability of diagnostic data. One of: "None" "Requested" "Complete" Value may be set to Requested to initiate the diagnostic test. When writing, the only allowed value is Requested. To ensure the use of the proper test parameters (the writable parameters in this object), the test parameters MUST be set either prior to or at the same time as (in the same SetParameterValues) setting the DiagnosticState to Requested. When requested, the CPE SHOULD wait until after completion of the communication session with the ACS before starting the diagnostic. When the diagnostic initiated by the ACS is completed (successfully or not), the CPE MUST establish a new connection to the ACS to allow the ACS to view the results, indicating the Event code "8 DIAGNOSTICS COMPLETE" in the Inform message.
Number of repetitions of the ping test to perform before reporting the results.
Timeout in milliseconds for the ping test.
Result parameter indicating the number of successful pings (those in which a successful response was received prior to the timeout) in the most recent ping test.
Result parameter indicating the number of failed pings in the most recent ping test.

Result parameter indicating the average response time in milliseconds over all repetitions with successful responses of the most recent ping test. If there were no successful responses, this value MUST be zero.

Result parameter indicating the minimum response time in milliseconds over all repetitions with successful responses of the most recent ping test. If there were no successful responses, this value MUST be zero.

Result parameter indicating the maximum response time in milliseconds over all repetitions with successful responses of the most recent ping test. If there were no successful responses, this value MUST be zero.

This object models the PTM layer properties specific to a layer 2 interafc of DSL modem used for Internet access on a CPE. This object is intended for a CPE with DSL modem WAN interface, and is exclusive of any other WAN*Link-Config object with a given WANConnectionDevice instance. The PTM Link Layer object exists when the WANDSLInterfaceConfig LinkEncapsulationSupported parameter includes any of: "G.992.3_Annex_K_PTM" "G_993.2_Annex_K_PTM" "G.994.1"
Enables or disables the link. On creation of a WANConnectionDevice, this object is disabled by default.
Status of the link. Enumeration of: "Up" "Down" "Initializing" "Unavailable"
The physical address of the interface.

PTM mode QoS priority low is the default value.
PTM QoS priority high is not default.
Enable/disable quality of service.
Scheduler algorithm for PTM connections with same precedence as this connection.
Weight of the MPAAL group associated with this PTM connection.
Precedence of the MPAAL group associated with this PTM connection.
Scheduler algorithm for PTM connections with same precedence as the default queue of this connection.
Default queue weight.
Default queue precedence,

Interface name.
Dropping algorithm used for this queue if congested. Enumeration of: "RED" "DT" "WRED" "BLUE"
WRED Low Class profile minimum threshold specified as a percentage of queue size.
WRED Low Class profile maximum threshold specified as a percentage of queue size.
WRED High Class profile minimum threshold specified as a percentage of queue size.
WRED High Class profile maximum threshold specified as a percentage of queue size.
Default queue minimum bit rate in bits-persecond.

This object holds per tunnel configuration and status parameters. Currently, only 1 tunnel is supported.
Is this session enabled.
User friendly name for this tunnel session. This can be anything the user chooses. It is only used by the UI to identify this session. It is not used internally.

DefaultMode: Only one WAN service can be on this layer2 interface. VlanMuxMode: for multiple vlan interface base on this layer2 interface. MultipleService Mode: for multiple service over this layer2 connection. For now, only DefaultMode is supported. We put this parameter here to make this object similar to the DSLLinkConfig object.
Indicates the state of the L2TP session.

This is an id that is created when the session is created. It must be passed to ppp when it tries to run over the tunnel. The l2tp LAC userspace daemon sends this info to ssk. ssk writes it into this param. Therefore, it is read-only.

Even though Linux does not create an interface for the l2tp tunnel, it is convenient for the CMS code to have an ifName to identify this object. That makes it consistent with the other link objects in the system. For now, the ifName will always be l2tp0.
which l2tp tunnel this session is created on. support multi session on single tunnel and multi session on multi tunnel.

This object models the POTS link layer properties specific to a single physical connection used for Internet access on a CPE. This object is intended for a CPE with a POTS WAN interface, and is exclusive of any other WAN
Enables or disables the link. On creation of a WANConnectionDevice, this object is disabled by default.
Status of the link. Enumeration of: "Up" "Down" "Dialing" "Connecting" "Unavailable"

Specifies a list of strings separated by semicolon (;), each string representing a phone number to connect to a particular ISP. The digits of the phone number follow the semantics of the ITU-T E.164 specification. Delimiters such as brackets or hyphens between the digits of a phone number are to be ignored by the CPE.
Information identifying the Internet Service Provider. The format of the string is vendor specific.
The number of times the CPE should attempt an Internet connection setup before returning error.
The number of seconds the CPE should wait between attempts to setup an Internet connection.
Specifies capabilities of the POTS modem - i.e., if it handles data (0), fax (1,2,2.0), voice (8), DSVD (80). Comma separated list of the following enumeration: "0" "1" "2" "2.0" "8" "80"
The modulation standard currently being used for data. Enumeration of: "V92" "V90" "V34" "V32bis" "V32"
The protocol standard currently being used for data transfers. Enumeration of: "V42_LAPM" "V42_MNP4" "V14" "V80"
The compression technology implemented on the modem. Enumeration of: "V42bis" "MNP5"
Capability for full duplex operation with data and voice.

This object enables configuration of IP connections on the WAN interface of a CPE. This object is intended only for all WANConnectionDevices not employing PPP addressing, and must not be active for WANConnectionDevices that do employ PPP addressing.

The time in seconds since the establishment of the connection after which connection termination is automatically initiated by the CPE. This occurs irrespective of whether the connection is being used or not. A value of 0 (zero) indicates that the connection is not to be shut down automatically.

Port mapping table. This table MUST contain all NAT port mappings associated with this connection, including static and dynamic port mappings programmatically created via local control protocol, such as UPnP. This table MUST NOT contain dynamic NAT binding entries associated with the normal operation of NAT. At most one entry in an instance of this table can exist with all of the same values for RemoteHost, ExternalPort, and PortMappingProtocol. If the ACS attempts to set the parameters of an existing entry such that this requirement would be violated, the CPE MUST reject the request. In this case, the SetParameterValues response MUST include a SetParameterValuesFault element for each parameter in the corresponding request whose modification would have resulted in such a violation. On creation of a new table entry, the CPE MUST choose default values for ExternalPort and PortMappingProtocol such that the new entry does not conflict with any existing entry.
The layout of this PortMapping object must match the layout of the PortMapping object under WANPPPConnection.
Enables or disables the port mapping instance. On creation, an entry is disabled by default.

Determines the time to live, in seconds, of a port- mapping lease. A value of 0 means the port mapping is static. Dynamic (non-static) port mappings count down towards 0. When value reaches 0, the port mapping is terminated and the entry is deleted.
As of 4.16L.02, this parameter is not used anymore. But it is left in the data model to avoid any compatibility issues with older config files.

This object contains statistics for all connections within the same WANConnectionDevice that share a common MAC address. The contents of this object should be identical for each such connection. This object is intended only for WANConnection- Devices that can support an Ethernet-layer on this interface (e.g., PPPoE, IPoE).
Total number of received packets that get dropped on this connection. Baseline:2 EthernetDiscardPacketsReceived
Total number of transmit errors on this connection. Baseline:2 EthernetDiscardPacketsSent
Total number of receive errors on this connection. Baseline:2 EthernetErrorsPacketsReceived
Total number of transmit error on this connection. Baseline:2 EthernetErrorsPacketsSent
Total number of bytes sent over all connections within the same WANConnectionDevice that share a common MAC address since the CPE was last reset.
